characters: MAGGIE IN THE HOSPITAL BREAK ROOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bedroom stuck in the 1970's. Felt wallpaper, cigarette smoke stains, thick dust. Pictures everywhere of a MAN (VINCENT) and a WOMAN (SANDY) in love. They couldn’t look happier. Young, full of life. On the bed, a Russian woman with a tortured Brooklyn accent, DAKA, rides on top of someone we’1ll soon meet. Daka is lost in her 30s, rough, tattooed, too much makeup, and somewhere underneath it all...beautiful. Furthermore, she’s pregnant. Who knows how long, she’s so damn skinny. Grinding away.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: You eat the breakfast yet? She’s talking to VINCENT (mostly VIN.) Whom she’s riding. He’s the guy from the pictures, although now in his 60s/70s. Beat-to-hell, raw, irreverent. He gave up on life years ago.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: (puffing a cigarette) You didn’t eat?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: I forget.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: How do you forget to eat?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: It happens so. Vincent returns his gaze to...the TV on top of his dresser. An old Abbott & Costello movie is playing. Daka adjusts herself, continues grinding on Vincent. Then...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You want go to breakfast? Sure. INT. NAT’S BROOKLYN DINER - LATER A greasy spoon in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. Vincent and Daka are in a booth eating breakfast. Daka is scarfing down Huevos Rancheros, like she hasn’t eaten in days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get reflux just looking at you.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: They have pill for this.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Bastards have a pill for everything. That’s a fact, lady. Killing us all, ten milligrams at a time. Vincent sifts through his pill pouch. Pulls out a dozen or so...the day’s dose.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where’s the water? Didn’t I ask for water?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Ask fuck again.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Coming here twenty years, still can’t get their shit together. Calling off to a Mexican server (JESUS.)

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus. Aqua. Pills. Jesus smiles, nods.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: I never take this pills.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Just crack and meth. That’s a better plan.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Vin. Stay off me. She reaches across the table for his toast.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want this toast. Jesus returns with a glass of water. Lots of ice.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Here you go, Mr. Vincent.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Can you put more ice in it? I want to make sure I choke while I’m swallowing my poison. Jesus is confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don’t want this ice.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Oh. Si.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Oh, si. Just like everyday I come in here. Aqua no hielo. No one really knows what to say. They've heard it all before. Daily.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Uno momento, Mr. Vincent. Jesus walks off, nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Uno momento. Vin takes a pill, swallows.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What did Jesus say to the Mexicans before he left?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: This I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Don’t do anything till I get back. Daka doesn’t laugh.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: You speak for Jesus is not right.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Really. From you? Vin takes another pill. Swallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standard bank. Vin'’s car’s parked outside. A very old convertible MG Spider in shit shape. INT. THE BANK — CONTINUOUS Vin’s sitting across from a mortgage counselor, TERRY. He’s reviewing paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: (pointing) That one there. Says the line’s been frozen.  Terry shuffles.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Got it. Yes. Let’s see...so...with these reverse mortgages you can only borrow a percentage of the equity you have in the house. That’s called the loan-to-value.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Don’t need a financial seminar. I own the damn thing outright. 40 years.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. Well...you did. But now, Since you’ve been getting monthly payments from us for the last... (searches the papers) eight years...you’ve reached the cash out limit. That’s that loan- to-value thing I just mentioned.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: The house is worth-

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: It was worth. Whatever it was worth. And I’m sure you know housing prices have fallen dramatically since the financial crisis. Right. Unless you’ve been living under a rock. His attempt at humor...not appreciated.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You do stand-up? Vin rises.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is my life here, pal. I need that money.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Mr. Canatella. There’s really nothing I can do. It is what it is.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Everybody's says that now. You know what it means, “You're fucked, and will remain fucked.” He walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m closing my accounts forthwith. You don’t get my business another day.

dialogues.speaker: THE TELLER LINE
dialogues.text: Vin waits in line, steaming. Ding. An electronic arrow points him to TELLER WINDOW #23.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER WINDOW
dialogues.text: Vin hands TELLER #23 his ATM card.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I want to close this account.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to hear that, sir. May I ask why?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Lady. You're just a spoke on a wheel, trying to make a living like the rest of us schmucks. I don’t want to tell you to go fuck yourself. Let’s just leave it at that.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: Okay. Tap, tap, tap on the keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: That’s one hundred twelve dollars and fourteen cents.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Small bills.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: No, sir...you’re overdrawn that much.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: It means you don’t-

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I know what overdrawn means.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: We've sent several notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. I can’t close my account.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: You can, when you get it back to zero. Vin takes his card. What’s to say. INT. VIN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Vin labors into the car. Daka is waiting in the passenger seat. He hands her a few crumpled bills.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What’s what?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: My shit is not lay-a-way. I am no JC Penny. Fuck face.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I’m a little tight right now. You know I’m good for it. Daka looks him over.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: I don’t make like before, Vin. Only few freaks like the belly. Understand. She gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have to save for maternity leave. You asshole. She heads off down the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: See you next week.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Extras when you do. Daka moves on, bag in hand, adjusting her junk. Vin drives off. A few NEIGHBORHOOD MEN whistle at Daka. She yells back at them.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not dog! Fuck face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The local dive bar. SMOKERS outside litter the sidewalk. The windows are painted with “Happy New Year” greetings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old neon. Older PATRONS. Vin sits at the bar next to LINDA and GUS, a weathered married couple in their late 60s. They’re dressed to the nines. The hanging TV set plays New Year’s Eve coverage from around the country. They're all fairly lit...although Vin’s in a class by himself. Very thick tongued.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: You have a good Christmas, Vin?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: (slurring) Best Christmas I ever had. No people. No presents. No bullshit. Just celebrating the birth of the baby Jesus. Tips his tumbler to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Ah, you don’t mean that, Mister.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What do you know what I mean, Linda? You a psychic now?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Ay, ease up there, Vinny. We're just talking.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You should get a talk show. You’re so damn good at it. The “Linda and Gus Just Fucking Talking Talk Show.” Vin flags the bartender, ROGER.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rog. Another Maker's. Roger steps over.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Vin...we got three hours till the ball drops there. Why don’t we give it a break for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Give what a break?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The liquor.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You're not gonna serve me?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: For a minute.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You know how much money I’ve spent in this dump over the years? Roger tries to keep it smooth.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Don't be like that, Vin. I’m watching out for you here.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Watching out for me? Vin stands, wobbles. He’s drunker than even he realized.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You serve poison to people everyday. So they can die while they’re alive. Now you’re watching out...is that right? Gus stands, tries to help Vin.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Let me give you a ride home.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Don’t touch me, Gus. Do not touch me. I will drive home drunk like I’ve done every night Roger here’s been watching out for me. Vin pushes free, walks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Happy New Year. He’s out. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - LATER The Spider whips into the driveway. Hits the picket fence on the neighbor's border. Crash. It topples. Hits his own mailbox on the other side. Crash. It flies onto the lawn. He puts the top up. Vin shuts the car off. Sits for a minute. Then steps out and swerves to the toppled mailbox. Gets on all fours, opens the door, gets the mail...pounds of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin stares at a mountain of unopened mail, overflowing a basket. He empties the basket onto the floor, then tosses the new mail into the empty basket. All sorted. INT. VIN’S LIVING ROOM - LATER Vin puts his feet up on a weathered coffee table, watching TV from his paisley pattered couch. The decor is feminine inspired, twenty years ago. Coverage of the Times Square New Year's Eve Celebration plays. Vin’s cat, FELIX THE CAT, jumps onto his lap. Starts to pur.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: There you are. Where’d you go tonight, ha? You out catting around... He rubs the cat all over. His only love.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I bet you’re hungry, aren’t you? He takes Felix in his arms, shuffles to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: The kitchen is trashed: dishes to China, mold, stacks of newspapers a decade old. Vin opens a can of gourmet cat food. Dumps it in a bowl. Felix waits patiently on the counter...the food arrives. He eats like there’s no tomorrow. Vin needs another drink. He holds his tumbler to the ice maker in the fridge door. It grinds. No ice. He opens the freezer door and grabs a glob of ice cubes stuck together, puts them on the counter. Grabs a hammer from the junk drawer. BANG. BANG. He smashes the ice into pieces, chips fly. BANG! He hits his finger.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: UGHHHH. Shit. AHHHH. Vin stumbles with the pain. His foot gets ever so close to an ice chip on the tile floor... Slip. Flip. Smack. Vin flies up in the air, lands on the floor. Crack! His head hits the tile hard. He’s out. Or dead.  10. Felix looks at his owner. Jumps down beside him. Laps up some blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV insert. The ball is dropping in Times Square. 5, 4, 3, 2, 1. Happy New Year. PEOPLE hug, kiss, celebrate. FADE TO BLACK. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - THE NEXT MORNING MEN screaming in Spanish. We pan away from Vin’s house, over towards the source of the racket. In the neighbor’s driveway, a moving truck is backing into the drive and ripping tree limbs along the way. Vin’s tree limbs. A LATIN MOVER is screaming instructions to the LATIN DRIVER.

dialogues.speaker: LATIN MOVER
dialogues.text: Alto! Alto! You hit the tree, man. Come on!

dialogues.speaker: LATIN DRIVER
dialogues.text: Meda, I can’t see it! He notices the roof: pealed like a sardine can.

dialogues.speaker: LATIN MOVER
dialogues.text: You broke the roof! Ay Dios mio! They fight on. INT. KITCHEN - VIN’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Vin'’s where we left him: face down on the kitchen floor. A small pool of blood sits stagnant under his face. The yelling outside irks him to consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Shut up out there. People are sleeping. He groans. Holds himself up. Felix the Cat stares from a safe distance. Vin sees the blood.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah, piss. He feels his face, and for the first time we see it: he looks like a prize fighter after the twelfth round.  11. A gash above his eye is the origin of the blood. It probably needs stitches. He’1ll never get them. Vin sits there for a second, collects himself. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Vin walks outside, searching for the commotion. He shields the sun from his eyes. The fighting Movers are still at it.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! What’s the problem? This is a neighborhood. People are sleeping. The Movers stop. Stare.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You comprende?! Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Habla English?

dialogues.speaker: LATIN MOVER
dialogues.text: We speak English, senor.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing here? Vin looks up, notices the tree ripped.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the?!? That’s my tree you assholes hit?! There's a large tree limb sitting on Vin’s car and across the fence (which he knocked down last night.)

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And my fence! My damn car!?! Silence. VINCENT (CONT’D) Do you speak English!?! Just then a car pulls up, parks in front of the house. A WOMAN in her late thirties steps out. This is MAGGIE, Vin’s new neighbor. She'd be prettier if she weren’t always so worried.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m calling the cops. Vin heads inside.  12.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me... He turns.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'm Maggie. I guess I’m your new neighbor. Really.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: So.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes. We’re moving in today.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I noticed that. These dipshits with you?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: They're with the moving company. Maggie walks to the fence, stands on her side. Looks around.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, boy.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Oh, shit...more like it. That fence is twenty years old. The car’s forty. And the tree’s older than me.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry. I don’t know what to...this is not the way to meet. She turns to the Movers.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you guys do this?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Of course, they did it. What are you stupid? Look at the scene. Maggie doesn’t take kindly to being called stupid.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. There’s no need to be rude. Okay. I’m just moving in here. I hired this company. Okay. Accidents happen.  13. A LITTLE BOY comes up to Maggie’s side. This is OLIVER. Twelve. Frail. Four eyes. Painfully awkward and very sensitive. He’s one of those invisible types.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Accidents happen. What’re you a fucking adjuster? Maggie puts her arm around Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Do you mind, mister? Vin looks at Oliver. Absorbs him.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That car’s an antique, missy. Worth a lot of money. She looks at the car. More like a piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'll figure out how to-

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You. You don’t have any money. No offense. You don’t look like you do. And I'll bet Chico and the Man over there are “off the books.” No, thank you, blondie, I’1l sue the moving company. Vin walks off.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can buck up for the tree and the fence. He hits the front door. Oliver looks up at his mom.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: That’s our new neighbor.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It’s gonna be a long life. INT. MAGGIE & OLIVER’S HOUSE - NIGHT Oliver's bedroom. The room has a bed in it, little else. The evening ritual is in progress: bedtime book time. Although...Oliver is the one reading: “The Giving Tree.” Maggie’s on a beanbag on the floor, nursing a Chardonnay.  14.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: (reading) “I wish that I could give you something, but I have nothing left.” I am just an old stump. “I don't need very much now," said the boy. “Just a quiet place to sit and rest. I am very tired." "Well," said the tree, straightening herself up as much as she could, "Well, an old stump is good for sitting and resting. Come, Boy, sit down. Sit down and rest." And the boy did. And the tree was happy. Maggie drinks her wine. She gets

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: God, that’s depressing. up.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: No, it’s not. The old tree was made to give. So to be able to give everything and have nothing left is the best life the tree could ever have. She tucks Oliver into bed. Kisses his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That’s a nice way to look at it. Need you to catch the bus tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It’s my first day.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Mine too. Can’t be late. Maggie goes to turn off the light.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Where’s the bus line?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Get on the internet in the morning. You're good at that. Good night, love.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Night. She turns the light off. Oliver settles into the darkness.  15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bus stop. Maggie’s old Corolla sits in the bus lane. Oliver’s outside the door, leaning in the window. He’s dressed in a Catholic School uniform. Maggie hands him a lunch box.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Peanut butter and bananas.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Thanks, mom.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Snack money in the pocket. You have your key?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Map?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What time you get out?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Straight home, ‘kay. Start your homework.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Okay. A bus pulls up behind Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (re: the bus) This is yours. See you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Wait. Ma...you’re not picking me-

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m in the bus lane, Oliver. Be good. Okay. I don’t need another ticket. Maggie blows him a kiss, pulls off. Oliver backs away from the curb, as the bus pulls in.  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riding the bus. Oliver's sandwiched between an OLD JEWISH LADY and a PIERCED HIPSTER. He’s looking at a Mapquest print out. INSERT —- THE MAP: AN “X” MARKS THE SCHOOL’S LOCATION - ST. FRANCIS de SALES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PACKS OF STUDENTS mosey towards the campus. A classic brick and stone Catholic School.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St. Francis de Sales Catholic School is just like any other middle school. Diverse. Modern. Noisy. Dozens of KIDS crowd the hallways, dig through lockers, socialize with FRIENDS. Oliver can’t open his locker. He tries the combination again...no dice. He looks around for help. No one makes eye contact. The tardy bell chimes. Oliver gives up, drags all his stuff with him. Rushes down the hallway. INT. BROTHER CRESPI’S CLASSROOM - MOMENTS LATER Religious Studies class. Brother Crespi stands in front of THIRTY CHATTY PRETEENS. Crespi’s in his thirties, preppy and full of new teacher idealism. Oliver stands at his side, he could pass out.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: Settle down. I know it’s hard to come back to school after three weeks of vaca...but your education must continue. Believe me, you need it. The kids settle in.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is Oliver. He’s joining us mid-stream here at St. Francis. We're happy to have him. Aren't we..? The CLASS speaks in unison, albeit bored and cynical.

dialogues.speaker: ENTIRE CLASS
dialogues.text: Welcome to St. Francis, Oliver.  17.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: Such genuine caring. Okay, Oliver, why don’t you lead us in morning prayer? Shit. Oliver is frozen. The class stares.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone does it sooner or later. Oliver’s turning red. He leans in to Brother Crespi, whispers something in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I think I’m Jewish.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: Okay. That’s good. (to the class) Oliver thinks he’s Jewish. A few KIDS speak out.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOM KIDS
dialogues.text: (on top of each other) So am I. I’m Buddhist. There is no God. Brother Crespi raises his hands before it gets out of control.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: We celebrate all religions in this classroom. That’s why we’re called... The kids complete:

dialogues.speaker: ENTIRE CLASS
dialogues.text: (with fun sarcasm) Religions of the World, with Brother Cary Crespi.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: Bravo. Now, I happen to be Catholic, which is the very best religion in the world. Because we have the most rules. But some of us are Buddhist, Agnostic, Baptist, Presbyterian, Christian, and “I don’t know.” Which seems to be the fastest growing religion on the planet. And now we have Oliver. Who “thinks he’s Jewish.” Which is a new one for us as well. But...it doesn’t preclude you from morning prayer duty. Bow your heads. Heads down. Oliver has no idea where to begin. Crespi whispers to him:  18.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Say anything you want. Doesn't have to be special. Oliver bows his head.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Dear... Silence.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: (whisper) God...etc, etc.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Dear God. Thank you. More silence.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: (whisper) Amen.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Amen. The class repeats.

dialogues.speaker: ENTIRE CLASS
dialogues.text: Amen. Oliver breathes. Crespi smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: You made it. Go grab your seat. Oliver walks to his desk.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's wipe the dust off that textbook, young ones. Chapter twelve. Catholic Saints. Books shuffle. Pages turn. Oliver sits down. Beyond embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horse track. Shitty cars litter the lot.

dialogues.speaker: THE TRACK BREEZEWAY
dialogues.text: Vin’s filing out his race form. He closes his eyes, puts the form to his temple. Channels the racing gods. It’s his ritual.  19.

dialogues.speaker: TRACKSIDE
dialogues.text: A TRUMPETER sounds the BUGLE CALL as JOCKEY’S on HORSES settle in their stalls. The gates open...and they’re off. Vin’s sitting in “his” booth. Eating lunch. Drinking. He’s always drinking.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Come on. Come on. Dig in. The horses fly around the track.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dig. One time. One damn time. And just like that, Vincent’s horse...loses.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch. He crumples up his race form. Throws it on the floor. It lands at a MAN’S FEET.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No need to get pissy, Vincenzo. You lose all the time. Should be comfortable by now. Vincent looks up and sees...Zucko. His bookie. Dirty fingernails. Hairy eyeballs.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Rough day. Zaucko sits. Takes a pull of Vin’s Maker's.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Help yourself.

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO
dialogues.text: I'm thirsty, Vin. And you owe me.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I don’t have it right now, kid. Got a situation I’m working out.

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO
dialogues.text: The thing is, if you’re breathing, we all have situation. I’m not a sole proprietor here, Vinny. Got my own people to answer to. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I just need a little time, you know.  20.

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO
dialogues.text: What do I tell ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: A month.

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO
dialogues.text: I always loved your jokes. They kill me. You’re funny, Vin.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I always pay, don’t I? Zucko hits Vin’s Makers again.

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO
dialogues.text: Split the difference. Ya got two weeks. Zucko stands.

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hear the inside on the fifth is “Lucky By Numbers.” Right. But you got your luck. So. Go the other way. He leaves. Vin pushes his lunch aside. Appetite gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gym class. Oliver’s straining with all his might, trying to do a sit-up. A PARTNER holds his feet. On the mat next to him, ROBERT OZINSKI, the school bully reps through sit-ups like a rabid Marine. COACH MITCHELL blows the whistle, asks the PARTNERS for the count. Oliver’s Partner holds up one finger.

dialogues.speaker: THE TRACK
dialogues.text: Relay races. Ozinski sprints past the finish line. He’s a specimen for a twelve-year-old. Oliver is at the farthest end of the track. Running in slow motion. He’s lapped by a SMALL ASIAN GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: CHIN-UP BARS
dialogues.text: Ozinski’s ripping off chin-ups like a baboon. As a- matter-of-fact, he looks like one. KIDS count off: fifteen, sixteen, seventeen. Oliver’s on the next bar, shaking like a leaf. He may die.  21. Finally, COACH MITCHELL blows the whistle. Oliver’s Partner holds up a goose egg.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MITCHELL
dialogues.text: Time. All right. Good job, kiddos. Ozinski drops to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MITCHELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're done. Exodus towards the lockers. Coach Mitchell taps Oliver, who’s still hell-bent on getting his chin to that bar. It’s not going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MITCHELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can let go now. Oliver looks down at the drop. He’s chicken shit. Coach grabs him by the back, lowers him like a feather.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MITCHELL
dialogues.text: You have PE at your last school?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MITCHELL
dialogues.text: Did you take it?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MITCHELL
dialogues.text: Go get changed. Oliver walks away, in the wrong direction.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MITCHELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The other way. Those doors. He stops, looks. Changes direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver enters the locker room. Most of the KIDS are fully dressed already, and leaving. Ozinski starts heckling the moment he sees Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: There’s the strong man. Laughs. One of Ozinski’s buddies (BROOKLYN) chimes in.  22.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKLYN
dialogues.text: “I think I’m Jewish.” More laughs. Oliver takes a seat in front of his locker.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: My name is Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: (like a retard) My name is Oliver. Just then Coach walks in.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MITCHELL
dialogues.text: You guys hear that bell? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MITCHELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That means get moving. Shuffling.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MITCHELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go on. Get to class. They're off.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MITCHELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Oliver) You need a map? Oliver nods.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MITCHELL
dialogues.text: Double time it or you'll be late. Oliver nods. Coach walks off. He opens his locker. It’s empty. His pants, uniform...everything’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Shit. EXT. ST. FRANCIS DE SALES —- SIDEWALKS - LATER School's out. KIDS everywhere: jumping in cars, riding bikes, walking home. It's easy to spot Oliver in the crowd, he’s the only student wearing short gym shorts, a tank top and sneakers.  23. As expected, STUDENTS comment, laugh, text, chide. It’s not been a good first day for Oliver. He reaches the crosswalk. Looks up at the street sign, it doesn’t look vaguely familiar. He crosses anyway.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER WALKING
dialogues.text: -- Oliver crosses a major Boulevard. Cars everywhere. -- He stops in the middle of a block. Looks around. Then turns and goes back in the direction from wince he came. -- Oliver walks in front of a row of houses. A DOG tears up and jumps on the picket fence, barking. Oliver runs off. -- Oliver reads a street sign. Thinks. Walks on. INT. VIN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Vin’s driving through major traffic. He pulls up next to a bus load of PUBLIC SCHOOL KIDS. They stare at him. He stares back. The light turns green, the bus pulls off. Then in tandem, the WHOLE WINDOW ROW OF KIDS flip him off. Damn kids. Vin lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER WALKING
dialogues.text: Finally, Oliver recognizes his block. He runs towards what he thinks is his house. Looks...that’s it. He’s home. EXT. MAGGIE & OLIVER’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Oliver, at the front door, reaches into his pocket for the key. Damn. He’s not wearing his pants. His key and phone were in the pockets of his stolen uniform. He could cry. But he’s not the type. He slumps down in resignation and sits on the cold concrete steps. VIN’S DRIVEWAY - CONTINUOUS Vin’s car pulls in haphazardly. He runs over some of the toppled fence. Curses, with the windows up...so it sounds like Charlie Brown’s parents. Vin climbs out of the car. Walks to the fallen mailbox, lowers himself onto the lawn, pulls mail out until...  24.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Sir? Vin hears something. Stops, looks around. Confused.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Take me, God. Don’t play with me. Oliver steps forward, down the walk.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It’s me, sir. Vin squints. Finally sees the kid.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Yeah. What?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I was wondering if I could use your phone?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: My phone?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: In my house?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: To call my mom. I’m locked out. I was in gym class and these kids took my pants and I had my- Vin cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I don’t need the whole story. Vin stares at the little shit. Pulls himself up off the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One call. Vin walks away. Oliver walks across the lawn and through the demolished fence into Vin’s yard.  25. INT. VIN’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Oliver’s on an old rotary phone in the kitchen. Vin’s fixing a Maker’s Mark in the background. Ring. Ring. Ring. Voicemail.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Hi, Mom. I...ah...lost my key for the house. So, I’m at the old guy’s next door. Oliver turns to Vin.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir...what’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Vincent.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Vincent. (whispers ) The mean one... The conversation trails. VIN’S LIVING ROOM - LATER Vin’s sitting in his La-Z-Boy, facing Oliver on the couch. Felix the Cat is sitting in Vin’s lap, staring at Oliver. They don’t get much company around here. The silence lasts forever. And ever. A little longer. Then...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Oliver. More silence.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Don’t you think it’s a little cold for shorts?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It’s a long story, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I’m sure it is. Silence.  26.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t like “sir.”

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Hmm. The phone rings. THE KITCHEN — CONTINUOUS Vin picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAT scan lab. Maggie’s in scrubs, whispering in the corner of the room. ANOTHER NURSE is manning the controls, as a PATIENT (seen through the glass) is slid into the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: tube.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: This is Maggie, Oliver's mom. Is this Vincent?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Your kid’s here.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes. I just got his message. Is that all right?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Is what all right?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That he stays there?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Stays here. Like what, stays here?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m at work and...we got a few more cases. So, I don’t get off for a couple of hours and I can’t get him the key anyway. I’m ina little bit of a bind right now...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You want me to baby-sit?  27.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Well, he’s hardly a baby. He won’t bother you. He’1ll just do his homework. Oliver walks into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Sir? Vin holds up his hand, shushes Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What’re you paying?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: For baby-sitting. I’m not a philanthropy.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Okay...ten dollars an hour.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Twelve. Maggie is amazed.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Fine. Great. Can I talk to him? Vin puts the phone down on the counter, walks off.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Hey. It’s for you. Oliver walks to the phone, picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: VIN'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Oliver and Vin are sitting on the couch watching an old Abbott & Costello movie. Vin’s smoking, drinking. Felix the Cat is sitting in Oliver’s lap. Vin’s not thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: He doesn’t like many people.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I’m good with animals, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Yeah. He doesn’t usually like people who say they’re good with animals.  28. Oliver laughs at the movie. It’s rare.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've never seen Abbott & Costello?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: No, sir. Are they old?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: No. They’re dead. That’s the oldest you can be.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Or the youngest. Time freezes when you die. Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Where’d you learn that?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: A book.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What book?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: A kid's book, sir. I doubt you know it. Little shit. Then...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: It’s dinner time. You hungry or something? Oliver looks at Vin, studies his face.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: A little, sir. Vincent looks annoyed. He’s the kind of guy that gets annoyed when someone wants something, even if he offered.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That figures. KITCHEN - VIN’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Vin’s scouring the kitchen, looking for something to feed the kid. All he finds is a tin of sardines and a package of Saltines. He cracks the sardines open. Arranges like it’s sushi. Decorates a dirty plate with concentric circles of sardines and stale crackers. Not bad.  29.

dialogues.speaker: VIN'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Oliver’s eating a sardine cracker sandwich. Watching the movie. Perfectly at home. Vin’s drinking his dinner, a huge stack of mail sitting on his lap. Bank statements, overdraft notices. He rips them up, one by one. His idea of filing. The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Probably your mother.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Probably, sir. Oliver doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I guess I’ll get that.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Vin aches his way out of the recliner.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Vin peeks out the peep hole, then opens the door for...Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hi. Vincent.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Yep. He doesn’t instinctively let her in.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thank you so much for watching Oliver. I just started a new job and...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I don’t need the whole story.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Ok. Right. Maggie digs in her purse and pulls out some cash.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. Three hours. Twelve dollars an hour-

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Thirty six.  30.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. She hands him two twenties.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I don’t have change. Of course. Really.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That’s...fine. Vin counts the money, puts it in his shirt’s breast pocket.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Where's his father? That’s personal.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Well. That’s a long story...see...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it then. A beat. We hear Oliver laughing in the background. Maggie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How come you don’t have anyone to watch this kid after school?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We just moved in-

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I was there.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You gonna pay for my fence?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: And the tree?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: The tree? How-

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Everything has a price. You're an adult, you should know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. How much?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I‘ll figure out something fair. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Let me know.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I can the watch the kid too. After school for a few hours. Same price. Maggie is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l1 do eleven bucks an hour if you supply the snacks. Little shit ate my last can of sardines. INT. MAGGIE & OLIVER’S HOUSE - LATER Maggie and Oliver sit at a tiny round table, kitchen. Oliver is chowing down on a frozen

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You ate at Vincent’s house, no?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Can we buy some sardines, ma?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Sure. Remind me next time we’re at the store.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You like him?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Vincent.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: He’s interesting. In an old, grouchy sort of way.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That he is. A beat. 31. off the dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, he offered to watch you after school.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: He did?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yep. I was thinking maybe that’s not such a horrible idea. It’s right next door. Would save me having to find a baby-sitter.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You'll be home though. Right.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Late mostly, baby. We have to eat. I have to work. Your father’s...not helpful. The new school isn’t cheap. Oliver eats, thinks.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I guess he’s too old to be dangerous and not too old to be too dangerous either. If you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That’s what I thought. Maybe we’ll give it a whirl. See what happens.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Sure. Then...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ma, are we still Jewish? INT. BROTHER CRESPI’S CLASSROOM - CONTINUOUS Crespi, teaching.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: What is a saint? Hands go up. Never Oliver’s. He’s doodling.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rachele. A tiny ASIAN GIRL answers.

dialogues.speaker: RACHELE
dialogues.text: Individuals who display and act out of exceptional holiness. 32.  33. Damn.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: Okay. That’s pretty perfect, Rachele. Thank you. Who can name a saint? Hands.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keesha.

dialogues.speaker: KEESHA
dialogues.text: St. Michael the Archangel.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: Great. He’s a classic. Jeremiah? A LATIN BOY answers.

dialogues.speaker: JERMIAH
dialogues.text: St. Jude.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: Good one. What’s he known for?

dialogues.speaker: JERMIAH
dialogues.text: He has a hospital. Laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: He sure does. Okay, anyone know a modern day saint? Bridgette? A tall, athletic girl pipes up.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGETTE
dialogues.text: Mother Theresa.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: Excellent. So...saints are human beings we celebrate for their dedication and commitment to other human beings. For their sacrifices. Their work to make society better for those around them and those that’1l come after them. A KID calls out from the back.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER KID
dialogues.text: You're a saint, Brother Crespi.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: Yes. I am. Thank you. Crespi turns on the Smart Board. The title on the presentation: “Saints Among Us.”  34.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And so, our semester project is thus aptly named: “Saints Among Us.” You're going to research an actual Catholic saint that inspires you... Oliver doodles a word: “Saint.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lockers. Maggie is packing up to go home after a long shift. Her supervisor, GLEN, finds her.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Robin called in sick today. Got about six cases backed up.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I have to pick up my son.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Ah. Got it. It’s double time, you know. She needs the money.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Doesn't happen that often. Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Let me see what I can do. INT. VIN’S LIVING ROOM - DAY Vin’s sleeping in his recliner. The phone rings. He opens his eyes, agitated.

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Vin picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Yeah?  35.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE IN THE HOSPITAL BREAK ROOM
dialogues.text: Maggie’s on her cell phone. She hears Vin’s voice, hangs up. Vin hears the click.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Cowards. Try to sell me something, go ahead. He hangs up. Moseys back.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL BREAK / SNACK ROOM
dialogues.text: Maggie can’t do it. Glen the Supervisor comes in.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: You ready? We’re seven deep now.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh. I’m-

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: All good, right? I already told scheduling we're all set.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s good. Let me just- (motions to the phone) Finalize... Glen exits.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: No problem. Maggie is stuck. INT. VIN’S LIVING ROOM - DAY Vin’s almost sleeping again...when that fucking phone rings. His eyes pop open. VIN’S KITCHEN - MOMENTS LATER Vin picks up the phone, battle ready.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What!?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Vincent?  36.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I’m gonna wait till you give your whole spiel before I hang up. Maggie has no idea how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Vincent? Vin’s equally confused.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Maggie? That’s a good one.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Your next door neighbor?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Who? Oh. What the hell do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School pickup. Oliver’s an ant amongst the THRONGS OF KIDS waiting for a ride home. He’s buried in a book, when Vin’s car putters in. A thorn amongst the black Crossovers. Vin scans the CROWD OF KIDS, spots Oliver. Honks his horn. Way too long. Everyone stares. Oliver looks up. Mortified. INT. VIN’S CAR - LATER Vin’s driving. Oliver’s still recovering. A large basket of clean laundry sits between them.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Better buckle up.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You’re not buckled.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: My life is my problem. Oliver buckles.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: This the way home?  37.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: No. Then...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s lay down some S.O.P. here.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I don’t know what S.O.P. means, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Standard Operating Procedure. You go where I go. Do what I say. Get your homework done somewhere along the way. And most importantly, don’t annoy me. I’m not happy when I’m annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Are you annoyed right now?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Not particularly.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Really. Vin stares at him. Smart ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin pulls into a convenience store. INT. VIN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Parks.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Here’s a quarter. Call your mom, tell her you’re wearing your seat belt.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Costs more than a quarter.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Since when.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Since before I was born.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with this country. Vin digs some more change out of the ashtray.  38.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If it’s more than that, call collect. Vin's out, to the 7-Eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver’s dialing a number, when FOUR KIDS ON SKATEBOARDS round the corner. It’s Ozinski, Brooklyn and TWO OTHER PUNKS. Oliver turns his back. That won’t work. They wheel right up.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: Hey. It’s dipshit.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKLYN
dialogues.text: You live in this neighborhood? Oliver doesn’t talk.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: Probably got detention cause a you. Asshole.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You probably got detention because you took my stuff.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: How do you know I took it? Ozinski flips his skateboard into his hand, moves in. OZINSKI (CONT’D) Fucking narc. INT. VIN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Vin’s back at the car. Leaning on his door, smoking a cigarette. Watching Oliver get knocked around. It’s entertaining for him. And embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ozinski slams Oliver hard into the payphone. His nose starts bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: You're a bleeder.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKLYN
dialogues.text: I got a band-aid.  39. Oliver does the unimaginable: he swings at Ozinski. Well, rather, he slaps him in the face. Ozinski barely moves.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: What was that supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKLYN
dialogues.text: He just slapped you. Oliver tries to run. Brooklyn slides his skateboard under him, and the little guy goes flying to the pavement. Ozinski rolls up. Wheelies his board, pins Oliver's chest.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Please...that hurts. From around the corner, Vin’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What’re you little shit heels doing? They turn to see Vincent, holding a tire iron.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That you Robert Ozinski?

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: No, sir. My name’s John.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Bullshit, you little prick. You’re Reesa’s kid. Reesa Ozinski. I recognize you from your fat Polish nose. Vin walks towards them.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just like your prick father’s nose. Guess the apple doesn’t fall too far from the rotten tree. Vin lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got a deal for you little bully shits. Whatever you do to the little guy there...I’m going to all of your mothers. Vin smashes a skateboard with the tire iron. It shatters.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ride this!  40. Scared to shit, the four haul-ass out of there. VINCENT (CONT’D) Get on, pencil dicks! Vin walks up to Oliver. Looks down at him. Offers his hand. Oliver hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need a paper invitation? Oliver takes his hand. Vin pulls him up to his feet, heads to the car. INT. VIN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Driving.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Who taught you...how to slap?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Just an instinct, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Well, you should unlearn that. Vin lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I'm allergic, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: To what?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Cigarette smoke. Vin rolls down his window, hangs his cigarette outside. Keeps smoking.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Your father never taught you how to take care of yourself?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: No, sir. He’s a pacifist.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Kid, this country wasn’t founded by tree huggers. That’s for sure. You gotta stand up for yourself or you get mowed down.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I’m small, if you haven’t noticed.  41.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: So was Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: That’s not a great comparison.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Indeed. Making a point though, fella. Small means nothing. It’s what you got in here. Vin points to his head.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Or here, sir. Oliver points to his heart. Vin looks at the little fella. This kid’s got something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An expensive, well-kept convalescent center. Vin'’s car pulls in and parks in a handicapped spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin and Oliver are walking down the hallway. Oliver's carrying the laundry basket. Vin’s putting on a lab coat, carrying an old-school, leather doctor's bag.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: This is like a mansion.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: When we get in there, don’t talk.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: How about you practice not talking now. Vin turns a corner.

dialogues.speaker: PATIENT ROOM
dialogues.text: A WOMAN lies in a bed, watching TV. This is Vin’s wife. SANDY. She has advanced Alzheimer's. Vin and Oliver enter.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: There you are, doctor.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Good to see you, Sandy.  42. Vin puts his doctor’s bag on the foot of her bed, digs in it. VINCENT (CONT’D) How're we feeling?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Today's my birthday. It’s not. Vin pulls out an old stethoscope.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, happy birthday. (to Oliver) Put that stuff in the drawers over there. Oliver complies.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s see what the old ticker sounds like. Vin moves bedside, puts the stethoscope to Sandy’s chest.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Can you tell them I don’t like the green beans, when they put the bacon bits chopped up in there with them. It’s too greasy for me. Vin moves some hair off Sandy’s face. Lightly touches her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You bet, Sandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Doctor” Vin and Oliver are sitting on a bench next to Sandy (in a wheelchair,) in front of a gorgeous pond, cluttered with ducks.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: They say I’m going home next week. They don’t.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That’s the plan. It’s not.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Is that your grandson?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Nope.  43. Sandy looks Oliver over.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Is he a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: What’s his specialty? Vin looks him over too.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE'S STATION
dialogues.text: Vin’s talking with Sandy’s nurse, ANA, a kind-eyed Filipino lady in her forties. She hands him a bundle of dirty laundry.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: You know, we can do the laundry here, Mr. Vincent. We have the service.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Gives me something to do. Vin hands the laundry off to Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Who’s your helper?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: He’s twelve bucks an hour.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It’s Oliver actually.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Oliver. I’m Ana. Vin heads off. Stops.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: She doesn’t like the green beans.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I’1l make a note, Mr. Vincent. Ana writes in a pad.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: She always liked broccoli. Broccoli's good. Vin walks off. Oliver catches up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. VINCENT’S GARAGE - LATER Oliver’s standing in a fight stance across from Vin, who’s wearing a bandana, holding a Maker’s Mark in one hand while leaning against a hanging heavy bag. Oliver punches the bag. It’s like a butterfly kiss.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That's just going to get you beat up real bad.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I don’t want to fight anyway.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: No one wants to fight, kid. You think I wanted to go to war? You think an eighteen year old wants to sit in a rice paddy while bullets are screaming past his ears on both sides?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: When was that?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You were there?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: No, I’m imagining it. Vincent steps back, thinks. VINCENT (CONT’D) All right. I’11 teach you one thing, it’s probably the only hope you got. If you do it right, you'll break his nose with one shot. Oliver is rattled.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Break his nose.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Relax, you won’t do it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie’s walking to her car after work. She’s exhausted. Just as she puts her key in the door...a MAN walks up.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Maggie?  45. She turns, clutches her purse.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I have mace.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I have papers. The man holds up an envelope. Moves closer.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: LA County Family court. He hands the papers to Maggie. She hates taking them.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As they say, “You've been served.” He turns off, stops.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean to scare you. Just a job. Maggie nods, leans against the car. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - LATER It's late. Maggie knocks on Vin’s door. INT. VIN’S HOUSE - LATER Vin’s leading Maggie into the den.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I’m working up an estimate on the fence. And we’re looking at three hundred on the tree. Not gonna negotiate with myself.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I get paid at end of next week.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That’s nice for you. Working for a living. Rough out there. In the den, we find Oliver asleep on the couch. Felix the Cat is curled up on top of him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’ll pay you of course for the extra time.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I wasn’t offering a rebate.  46. Maggie scoops up a sleeping Oliver. VINCENT (CONT’D) What you been crying about? It's very obvious that Maggie’s been bawling.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s a long story.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: ‘Kay. What’s the punchline?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oliver's father wants custody. Vin thinks.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: There goes my job security. Maggie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That could've gone either way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Classic dumpy titty-bar in a rundown industrial strip. Vin’s sitting in his car in the parking lot. Waiting. Daka eventually comes rolling out a side door. Spots Vin. Walks his way. INT. VIN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Daka hops in, pissed.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Who pissed in your Cheerios?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: I can dance no more.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That a surprise?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Vin. I need this money.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: The self-employed racket is a tough road, I’'ll say that.  47.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: I should sue these. It’s...the word...discrimination. Against the pregnant woman. Yes?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I think you have case.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: (rubs belly) This bump costing me much money.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Nowhere near what he’s gonna cost ya.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: It’s not a “he.”

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: It’s a she?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: I do not wish for boy. Boys are fucks.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You don’t know?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: What do I know?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: The sex of the baby?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: How do I know this, Vin? I look like the psychic to you?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: They have technologies-—

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: I know what they have. Maybe I ask “employer” to fax insurance card to pay ultrasound. Yes? Vin gets it. INT. OBGYN’S EXAMINING ROOM - LATER Daka has her legs up in stirrups, as an ULTRASOUND TECH squirts gel on her belly in preparation for an ultrasound.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: This is cold.  48.

dialogues.speaker: ULTRASOUND TECH
dialogues.text: Sorry. Forgot to tell you that. It’s cold. But just for a minute. The Tech places the wand on Daka’s belly. ULTRASOUND TECH (CONT’D) I’m gonna move this around here and take some pictures of the baby.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: For taking pictures?

dialogues.speaker: ULTRASOUND TECH
dialogues.text: Well. Sort of. More like images. (motions to the monitor) Daka looks at the monitor. ULTRASOUND TECH (CONT’D) It’s pretty cool. See...there... Right...there. That’s the head.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: This is very big head. Maybe good.

dialogues.speaker: ULTRASOUND TECH
dialogues.text: Biggest part at this age. Adjusts the wand. ULTRASOUND TECH (CONT’D) And these are her little legs.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: She? You see this?

dialogues.speaker: ULTRASOUND TECH
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s a girl. You didn’t know? I'm sorry, did you not want to know? Daka could cry. But she won’t, she’s far too tough.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: No. It’s good to know. INT. OBGYN’S LOBBY - LATER Vin and Daka are checking out with a MEDICAL RECEPTIONIST. Vin is digging through his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What’s my deductible running?

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I couldn't verify her with your insurance, Mr. Canatella.  49. Daka butts in.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: We are just married.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That happened.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Yep. Told my insurance. You know how slow they are. Paperwork. Bureaucracy. State of the medical profession in general.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Don’t let him started. The Receptionist doesn't believe a word of this.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What’s that deductible run?

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Twenty dollars. Daka puts her head on Vin’s shoulder. Plays the part.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Thank you, sugar plum. Vin forks over a twenty.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: (under his breath) You owe me, lady. INT. ST. FRANCIS DE SALES - GYMNASIUM —- CONTINUOUS Dodge ball in progress. TWO TEAMS OF BOYS compete, throwing the ball as hard as they can at each other. Coach Mitchell’s on the opposite side of the gym, working on basketball drills with the GIRLS. Ozinski and Brooklyn are mowing down their OPPONENTS one after another, until only Oliver remains. He’s hard to hit, he’s so tiny. Ozinski has the ball.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: Get ready for a red ass, shit bag. He runs. Throws. Oliver jumps. The ball bounces under him and hits the wall, heading back towards Ozinski.  50. Oliver runs for the ball, as fast as his fawn legs will take him. It’s like slow motion. At the half line...the ball is feet away from crossing back onto Ozinski’s side. Oliver dives for it. Thud. He lands hard on the gym floor, his face smacks the half line. Ozinski grabs the ball. Smiles. Runs toward Oliver. OZINSKI (CONT’D) Say your prayers, you little pussy. Ozinski winds up. Oliver stands, trying to get the hell out of there. Ozinski’s a few feet away. He hurls the ball at Oliver's mug... Thwwapppppp. Right on the kisser. This is bad. Oliver’s glasses fly off his head. He crashes to the floor in a heap. Both hands over his face. Silence. You could hear a pin drop. KIDS gather around Oliver, concerned, curious, scared. He’s not moving. Even Ozinski looks worried. He walks over, closer to Oliver. A whistle blows. Coach Mitchell runs across the gym towards the scene. He gets there, just as Oliver lifts his head, uncovers his face. Blood everywhere. Coach Mitchell pushes through the crowd. Ozinski backs up. Out of nowhere, Oliver screams, a guttural kind of attack call.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You mother fucking, ass-face, dick bag... He has the wildest, animalistic look in his eyes. And he’s running directly at Ozinski. The entire class is frozen in disbelief...what the hell is he doing?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Asshole, cock sucking, son-of-a- whore... With his hand in a sort of death grip-blow, he hits Ozinski square in the nose...driving his schnoz up into his brain. Splickkkk! Ozinski’s nose explodes with blood. He falls flat backwards, passing out along the way. Thud. Ozinski smacks down on the gym floor. Game over.  51. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - LATER Oliver runs up to the house, bangs on the front door. Waits. Bangs again. Waits. Finally, Daka opens the door, wearing one of Vin’s old robes.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: What is for you?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: I am Daka. You are who?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I’m Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Why you bang door so much?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: He’s hard of hearing. Vin screams from within.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Let him in.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Don’t yell at me!? Daka opens the door wide for Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck face is yeller. INT. VIN’S HOUSE - THE DEN - LATER Vin and Daka are sitting on the couch. Oliver’s standing in front of them, his eyeglasses are patched together with tape.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: (a tinge of pride) You broke his nose.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I think so. There was blood everywhere. You should have seen it.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You must have hit it just right. Let me see.  52. Oliver demonstrates: the hand position, the stance.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: You teach him fighting?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: He’s a runt. Needs to learn how to defend himself. Daka stands, had enough.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Where’s this money?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: It’s on the dresser.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Any extras?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: It’s all there. Minus the deductible. Daka walks off.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: You don’t teach the children. Look at you. She’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: A lady of the night.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What’s that? Vin lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: One of the more honest ways to make a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin and Oliver are staring up at the betting board.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: The board tells you what the day’s action looks like. Race number. Who’s running, riding, so forth.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What’s 20 slash 1?  53.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Odds. Some bookie outta Vegas thinks that horse has a one in twenty chance of winning.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: And what do you get if he does?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Twenty times your money.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: That’s a good deal.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: If you win. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: THE ENCLOSURE
dialogues.text: Vin and Oliver stand at the fence, watching HORSES and JOCKEYS walk. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: (re: a horse) That one there with the wraps...is The kid is fast. a dog.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Doesn't sound like a compliment.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: The odds of him winning are astronomical.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: We should take him across the board.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Don’t get ahead of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: TRACKSIDE
dialogues.text: Vin’s in his “booth.” Eyes closed, holding his racing form to his temple. Oliver’s studying his own race form.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What’s a-

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You see what I’m doing here?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Praying?  54.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Praying?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: That’s what it looks like.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I thought we talked about talking. Vin opens his eyes. Annoyed. Oliver could care.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What’s a trifecta?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You pick three horses to finish 1-2- 3, in the order they come in. High risk, high reward.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Sounds improbable.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: If you’re gonna gamble, you might as well have the chance to win big. Oliver scans the form, thinks.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Wishful Thinking. Sweeter Lady. Champagne Flute. One, two, three. 800 to l.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: How much money you got? Oliver un-Velcros his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Seven dollars.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Lunch money?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You might as well learn the hard way. Vin pulls some cash from his wallet. Stands.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll go in with you. That’s called mitigation. They're off to the betting window.  55.

dialogues.speaker: THE FINISH LINE
dialogues.text: The HORSES fly across. One. Two. Three. We whip over to Vin and Oliver standing at the rail, screaming like school kids. They hit it! The trifecta. For the first time we see Vin’s smile. It’s the kind of smile that lights up a life. As Oliver jumps up and down...Vin catches Zucko in the stands. He crumples his race form and starts to throw his usual “just lost” tantrum. It’s a good act. Oliver’s confused.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: We won? Didn’t we win?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Roll with it, kid. Without missing a beat, Oliver throws his hands in the air. Tosses his race form.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Son-of-a-bitch. Damn good.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Son-of-a-bitch. Vin kicks his chair, walks off. Oliver follows.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Mother fuckers. Zucko shakes his head at the losers.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: (under ) Ease up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin’s practically running. Ducking in, out, around and between cars, a plastic shopping bag in his hand. Oliver’s on his tail. INT. VIN’S CAR - LATER A wad of cash sits between the two. $5,600 to be exact.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Your mom can’t know about this.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Exactly. Oliver nods.  56.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She could really use it though.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Not if she knows where it came from.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You keep my half for me? Vin knows that’s not smart.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Well. I don’t want. Let’s not go there.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What am I going to do with it? INT. THE BANK — CONTINUOUS Vin and Oliver sit at the banker’s desk, waiting. Terry strolls up.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. He recognizes Vincent.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Canatella.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Kind of you to remember. Need to open up a savings account for my grandson here. Terry has a seat. Vin slides a stack of cash across the desk.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Never too young to start banking. Vin slides over a few more bills

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: And this'll get my account back to zero. Close me out, while you’re tapping away there. Vin smiles a fuck you at him.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Oliver) Don’t grow up to be a pencil pusher, kiddo. They’re spineless.  57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin is dancing solo to Steely Dan's, “Do It Again.” He’s wasted. Maker’s in one hand, a smoke in the other. His dance is a bizarre mix of slow-motion Tai Chi moves and yoga poses. In it we see the punch he taught Oliver. From the bar, Oliver watches. Perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: Celebration dinner. Vin and Oliver are bellied up to the bar, eating a feast of bar food. Burgers, fries, mozzarella sticks, onion rings, Coke, a few Maker's Marks. Oliver slurps his drink to the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You want another?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes, please.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Go for it. We’re living today. Oliver calls out weakly to the bartender (Roger.)

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You kids. Damn small talkers. No point in yapping if nobody's listening. Let’s hear it. Oliver belts out.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Can't get nothing in this life without being heard. Roger walks over.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Another Coke, please.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You can hit me while you’re at it there to, Rog. Roger knows Vin is wasted.  Vin digs process. drink. 58.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I’m all out Maker's, Vin. You cleaned me out.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Don’t lie to me, Roger. Be a man.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Vin. And he shouldn't be sitting at the bar. some cash out of his pocket. It’s a slow He tosses too much on the bar. Grabs his

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: We're going to find another place to our spend money.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: He’s just doing his job, Vin. Vin stares at Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Turncoats. Everywhere you look. No loyalty anymore. Everyone taking care of themselves in the old U.S. of A. That’s why we’re falling apart. Vin drains his wet ice, then smashes his glass on the bar. It shatters. His hand is ripped open.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Damnit, Vin.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Just a cut, pal. I’ve had a lot of them. Vin gets woozy, leans into Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s get you home, kiddo. Got homework to do. He passes out. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - NIGHT - LATER A taxi pulls into the driveway. The headlights illuminate a very pissed off Maggie, standing on Vin’s lawn. Vin and Oliver climb out of the car. Vin’s hand is bandaged.  59.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Hi, mom.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to Vin) Where the hell’s your car?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It broke down.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: It broke down.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Really. I don’t appreciate you taking him anywhere without asking me.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: This is gonna be fun.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Don’t be a smart ass for once. I need to know where my son is at all times, okay? Oliver slumps off. Oliver goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: We went to eat.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: He should starve?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Get inside Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Mom-

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Good night, Vin.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He’s fighting at school. You know about this?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Mentioned something like that.  60.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Great. He tells you. Not his mother.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: If you haven’t noticed...you’re not home much. Kinda hard to have a conversation with someone who’s not there.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I love it when people like you give people like me advice. Especially parenting advice.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I didn’t sign on for hormones here, deary. That’1ll cost you 15 bucks an hour.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You don’t have kids. You don’t have anything to think about but yourself. Vin starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What do you know about me? Really? Tell me. I’d love it. Vin stops. Maggie thinks.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Okay. You're right. I don’t know a whole lot about you. Because you don’t want much known. So you act like a prick and everyone stays away.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: If it ain’t broken...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It is broken. Look at it. Vin goes into his house. Gets the last word in before he closes the door.
