dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I’m up to 40 hours this week. 41 starts time-and-a-half. He’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver’s sitting on a bench outside the Principal's office.  61. Across from him, Ozinski’s sitting with his MOTHER (REESA.) Ozinski’s nose is bandaged like a prize fighter’s.

dialogues.speaker: REESA
dialogues.text: (to Oliver) You're a real tiny fella, aren’t ya.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: REESA
dialogues.text: You take Judo or something. Ozinski is embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: Ma.

dialogues.speaker: REESA
dialogues.text: Shut your face. You don’t talk for a month. Ozinski slumps.

dialogues.speaker: REESA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm glad it was a little shit that knocked the snot outta-ya. Now ya got no excuses. INT. PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Maggie’s sitting across from PRINCIPAL O'BRIEN, a puffy- faced official looking gent in his fifties. Maggie’s reading a report.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I can’t even say these words.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: They’re...creative.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That’s one way to put it. PRINCIPAL O’BRIEN Adjusting to a new school is tough on children at this age. At any age. So, I don’t want to minimize that...but is there anything else going on that we should be aware of?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t even know where to start.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: How about his father?  62.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Well. Please. That’1l take up your whole day. We’re in the middle of a divorce. Oliver's father...was sleeping with his assistant. And our accountant. And her assistant. And my hairdresser. While she was still cutting my hair. That was fun. Now he’s filed for custody of Oliver. Full custody. And he won't pay support till he gets his way. You see. Plus he’s a lawyer, so. So. I just took Oliver away as fast as I could and took this job at Mission Hills. I’m a CAT scan tech, so I see a lot of rough situations. Tumors. Cancer. Cysts. Clots. All that. And of course, I know what I see and I can’t say anything to people. Which is miserable, as you can imagine. And I work really late, trying to get our act together. Give Oliver a better education and a semi- normal life. And fight David and this custody shit. Excuse me. That’s his name. David. My ex. He never wanted kids anyway. He just doesn’t want me to be happy. Oliver's adopted. Do you know that? How would you. I’m not able to have kids. Something about my Fallopian tubes being twisted. I think they were just recoiling from David's sperm. Maggie reaches for a tissue.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you mind? Principal O’Brien shakes his head “no.” He has no words.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sure all of this has permeated into Oliver’s little being. And as they do in these situations...he’s acting out. Right? Principal O’Brien smiles. Maggie blows her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detention. Two adjacent bathroom stalls. Oliver’s in one, Ozinski in the other. They’re scrubbing the shitters, floors, walls, et al with scouring pads, toothbrushes. Quiet. Finally Ozinski breaks the silence.  63.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: My real name’s Robert. Ozinski is my last name. People call me Ozinski cause Crespi called me that last year. Now everyone calls me that. Oliver stops scrubbing. OZINSKI (CONT’D) I don’t really like it. Ozinski. Just too many kids call me that now, so it’s not like I can go ‘round all day and tell ‘em, “Dick wad, don’t call me Ozinski, my name’s Robert.” Cause I would spend my whole life doin’ that. Oliver stands, takes a piss. Then. OZINSKI (CONT’D) You takin a wiz?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Sorry, can’t hold it.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: Robert was my dad’s name. So, I’m a junior. He’s not around though. I don’t really know him, cause he left when I was a baby.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: My dad’s not around either. He did some bad things to my mom and so we left and I haven’t seen him ina while.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: No shit. Oliver flushes. Ozinski shuffles around. Then, Oliver's cell phone slides under the stall, followed by his house keys. OZINSKI (CONT’D) Your dad the one that taught ya how ta fight? Oliver takes his stuff.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: No. My baby sitter.  64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tacky office. Vin’s sitting across from the rehab director, SHIRLEY JORSTIN, a tight-lipped, tough egg in her 50s.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: There’s plenty of affordable health care options, Mr. Canatella. Sunnyside’s pricey. It’s not for everyone.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: My Sandy, she’s gotta have the best. So, I’1ll just figure this thing out. She hands him a folder: invoices, bills, statements.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: You’re months behind. We’re not in the credit business, as you know.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I get that. Vin looks inside, just a glance is enough to know he’s fucked.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: So...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: So, what’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: We need payment in full and three months in advance.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: By tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: We'll transfer her wherever you decide to put her.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Put her. That’s it. Or we get the boot?

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: That’s not the best way to phrase what’s happening.  65. Vin stands, pissed.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What is the best way to phrase it?

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: It is what it is. Vin takes a deep breath. Exhales slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin’s pushing Sandy around the pond. He’s wearing his doctor’s getup.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: I can’t wait for autumn. They plant the most beautiful mums all around the water.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Yep. Vin parks in front of their bench.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Every color you can imagine. I don’t know where they get them all.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: At the garden store. Sandy laughs. Touches his hand.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: You've always been so funny, Vin. Vin...she said Vin.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Sandy. A beat. Sandy looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s me, babe. Vin. And just like that, she’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: The ducks eat them though. We have to shoo them away. It’s sucha shame. Vin could die. It’s just too much.  66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin gets the dirty laundry bag from Ana. The ritual.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: It’s a lot lighter.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: She didn’t change much this week.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Easier on my back. Vin reaches into his pocket, pulls out some cash. A few wrinkled bills. He hands them to Ana.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think we can get some plants or something for the room.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Sure. I can have the concierge order something.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Mums. Or the like. I’m not a florist. He gets a few more bucks.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. For the trouble.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: No. No, sir, Mr. Vincent. This is my job. I take care of people. Please.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You go way beyond doing your job, Ana. You been an angel for my Sandy. He puts the money in her smock pocket. Ana’s practically blushing.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. Vincent. We don’t make habit now. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Deal. I’m shit broke anyway. She laughs on her way out.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I go tell the concierge.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Thanks, doll.  67. Ana disappears behind the station. Vin looks at the cabinet on the wall behind the counter: full of meds. He looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neighborhood is lined with decrepid houses, iron gates shielding every window and door. Vin sits in his car outside one of the more indigent shacks. Sunglasses and a hat conceal his mug. After too long...Daka comes waddling out of the house with a paper bag. Leans into the window.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Hundred bucks? I pay more than that for one prescription. Daka pulls bottles of meds out of the bag. Names them.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: For the epilepsy. Prostate flaring. To soften the shitting.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That should have some value.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: And to piss stronger.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Five hundred bucks. That stuff is high dollar.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: He say one hundred, take or leave it. You can’t sell this to get high. You must to find some freak or old fuck. Vin just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I’1l take the hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin’s at the bank, standing at TELLER WIDOW #23 again.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: You're account’s closed, Mr. Canatella.  68.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I know that. Withdraw from my grandson’s account there. I should be on it. Vin hands her his ID. She doesn’t think anything about it.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: How much, sir?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What’s the balance?

dialogues.speaker: THE TRACK BREEZEWAY
dialogues.text: Vin’s standing below the board, holding his race form to his temple. Communicating with the racing gods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin slides a wad of cash through the window. Huge bet.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Lucky Lincoln. New Dime and Sammy’s Savior. One, two, three in the third. The ATTENDANT takes the cash.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s going to make me all better, my friend. Vin collects the ticket. Rubs it for good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin’s watching the race on the bar TV. The race trumpet blows. The HORSES writhe in their stalls. The buzzer sounds. The gates fly open. And...they’re off. Vin can’t watch, he closes his eyes. Takes a long drink of his Maker’s. Puffs his cigarette. Listens. The ANNOUNCER calls the race.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And that’s New Dime taking the early lead on the rails, followed by Pretty Patty and Lucky Lincoln. The Announcer keeps barking in the background. Vin never opens his eyes.  69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin’s walking towards his car. He lost. It’s in his gait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin’s slumped, ruined in his mind. Head down. Cigarette dangling from his lips. Gus and Linda are sitting on their regular stools, playing Kino.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Vin give me a number?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Five grand.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: A Kino number.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You got five grand I can borrow, Gus? I’1l1 probably die before I pay you back even.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You serious?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Dead serious.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: If I had five grand, I wouldn’t be sitting here. Let me tell ya. We'd be on that Carnival Cruise ship somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: The Alaskan one, Gus. They say that one’s the prettiest.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Whatever one. Eating the buffet. They say those buffets are like something else. Endless crab and lobster and salad bar.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: The drinks are gratis too. Champagne in the morning with orange juice. They gotta name for it...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Mimosa.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: That’s it.  70. Vin stands, lays some money on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: (calls out to Roger) Rog. Get these two some Mimosas on me.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (surprised in the least) Oh. That’s sweet of ya, Vin. Vin walks off.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I hope you two get to that cruise one day. He leaves. Gus and Linda are in shock.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: That was real nice a him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin’s car labors through traffic. Endless traffic. EXT. VIN’S DRIVEWAY - LATER He pulls into his driveway. Parks. INT. VIN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Vin sits there. Looking at his house. His life. What now? INT. VIN’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Vin walks in. Shuts the door behind him. Turns when he hears...

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO
dialogues.text: You must think I’m not a very serious person, Vinny. How the hell did he get here?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You broke into my house?

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO
dialogues.text: The back door was “ajar.”

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You have no right to be here. How the hell do you know where I live?  71.

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO
dialogues.text: I do homework on assholes that owe money. Another THUG walks into the room from the bedroom. This is ANTWAN. Big, dirty. He’s carrying an antique jewelry box.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That's my wife’s, you son-of-a- bitch. Vin makes a move for the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m calling the police. Zucko stands, pulls out a gun.

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO
dialogues.text: You think that’s realistic? We’re just gonna sit here and let you pick up a phone and dial 911. Are you that old? Or that stupid? Vin turns to Antwan, yanks the jewelry box out of his hands.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Get the hell away from that. Antwan pushes Vin. He flies across the room. Hits the fireplace wall. Jewelry everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO
dialogues.text: You always have to take the hard way, Vin. Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: It’s more interesting. Vin rolls up his sleeves. Preparing to fight.

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO
dialogues.text: It’s more painful. Even I know that. Vin takes a step towards Antwan.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Let’s do it then.

dialogues.speaker: ANTWAN
dialogues.text: This mother fucker’s crazy.

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO
dialogues.text: Don’t kill him. But do get close. Vin takes another step. Stops. Something’s wrong. He’s wobbly. He grabs his head. Shakes it.  72.

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing, old man? Vin is blurry eyed. He drops to his knees. Hard. His eyes roll back in his head. It looks like a seizure.

dialogues.speaker: ANTWAN
dialogues.text: He’s dying, man. Vin falls face first onto the floor. Thud. BLACK OUT.

dialogues.speaker: ZUCKO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (in the darkness) Don’t touch him. Leave that shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver's walking out of the school with Ozinski.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: I have a cousin that’s Jewish. He had a big shit party when he turned 13.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: A barmitzah.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s it. Biggest party I ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It’s a coming-of-age ceremony. Supposedly a boy becomes a man at that age. Ozinski thinks long and hard. It hurts.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: Nah. My cousin ain’t no man. He’s a little pussy. His wiener ain't even shaved.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Circumcised. They stop at Ozinski’s bike, chained to a rack.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: You know a lotta fancy words. You’re like an Einstein. Oliver smiles.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I read a lot.  73.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: That’s cool. See ya tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yep. Bye, Robert. Ozinski nods. Oliver walks away. Then...

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: Hey, how come ya don’t have a bike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver’s riding on the back of Ozinski'’s bike. Scared for his life, but loving every minute of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ozinski and Oliver arrive in front of Vin’s house. Oliver jumps off the bike.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: Ya think I could meet the old bastard?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Sure. Just know he’s not real friendly at first. It takes hima long time to warm up. Ozinski parks his bike. INT. VIN’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Oliver keys in. Ozinski right on his tail. Something's not right, the house, the energy.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX THE CAT
dialogues.text: Meow. Meow. Felix rushes up to Oliver, hides behind his legs. Oliver walks into the room...and sees...Vin. Sprawled out on the floor, face first. Still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAT Scan lab. Maggie and ANOTHER NURSE are strapping Vin in. His eyes are open, but no one’s home.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hi, Vincent. It’s me Maggie. Oliver’s mom. He looks blankly at her.  74.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're going to put you in this machine here and run some tests, okay? It won’t hurt a bit.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER NURSE
dialogues.text: He can’t understand you, Maggie. Maggie nods. Upset. Vincent grabs her hand. Holds it. He understands.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: There you are. This takes about thirty minutes, okay? Vin says, “I understand” with his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: THE WAITING ROOM
dialogues.text: Oliver’s sitting in the waiting area. Amongst STRANGERS. Maggie walks in, worried, looking for her son. Finally she sees him...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: He okay, ma? She puts her arms around him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You’re such a brave little man.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: We thought he was dead.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Who’s we?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Robert Ozinski and I.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: The bully kid?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: We're friends. Since I broke his nose.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t even know what you’re doing anymore. Maggie starts to get teary, she rubs Oliver’s head.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Mother. Stop feeling sorry for me. And yourself. We're doing good. You're working hard, every day and we need the money. It’s okay.  75. Holy shit. Maggie is speechless, he’s a grown-up all of a sudden.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I think he’s had a stroke. You know what that is?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I've seen some billboards. “Know the signs of a stroke and call 911 immediately.” But they never say what the signs are so...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s a blockage in a brain artery. Oliver knows this is serious.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: That’s not good. Maggie puts her arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crespi’s class. Oliver’s standing in front of the darkened classroom, presenting, using the Smart Board.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I chose Saint William of Rochester, the patron saint of adopted children. Oliver clicks the Smart Board and a picture of Saint William pops up on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As a young man, William led a “wild and misspent youth.” Which included gambling, womanizing, drinking and other things considered inappropriate-— Brother Crespi interrupts (from the back of the room.)

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: Why did you chose Saint William? Throughout, Oliver clicks through slides on the Smart Board.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Well, he found a baby on the church steps and took it in and raised it as his own. He named him David. Click.  76.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then years later he went ona pilgrimage to the Holy Land with his son. And David went, like...crazy, and clubbed Saint William and cut his throat and then robbed the body. The slides are stock footage pictures of a crime scene. Blood. Mayhem.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: Ouch. Okay. Didn’t see that coming.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It’s a pretty interesting story. Which is why I chose it. The other saints I looked at were all so... “saintly” I guess.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: What does “saintly” mean to you?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I don’t really believe in saints and all that stuff. I mean, it seems like St. William gets to be a saint just because he was killed by the boy he adopted. These days people get killed all the time. They don’t get to be saint for it.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: So you don’t think we have saints living amongst us?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I don’t know any.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: Thank you, Oliver. Oliver walks to his seat. Brother Crespi moves to the front of the class.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Despite young Oliver’s reticence. I believe there are saints all around us today. They might never be recognized as such by a religion, but they’re every bit as important to our society as the saints in the textbook. He flips on the Smart Board: “Modern Day Saints” is the heading.  77.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thus, you're going to research someone you know, or know of, and determine if they have the qualities of a saint. Hence the catchy title: Modern Day Saints. Hands go up, lots of questions. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - LATER Oliver’s walking home from school. He sees SOMEONE sitting on Vin’s steps. It’s Daka.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Where’s is he? The car is there.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: He’s in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Why for? Oliver just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie, Oliver and Daka are walking down a hallway of PATIENT rooms.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: How do you and Vincent know each other?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: I work for this man.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Doing what?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Working for him. Maggie looks at Oliver. He’s buttoned up. INT. VIN’S HOSPITAL ROOM —- MOMENTS LATER Vin’s lying in bed, wide-eyed. He looks pissed. A SPEECH THERAPIST is trying to “therapize” Vin. The stroke has caused Aphasia and language apraxia. It’s a_struggle for Vin to talk, and hard to understand. The Speech Therapist holds up a flash card with the word “Dog” printed on it.  78.

dialogues.speaker: SPEECH THERAPIST
dialogues.text: Try to sound it out. Vin pretends to think, then holds up his middle finger.

dialogues.speaker: SPEECH THERAPIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not quite. Vin holds up the other middle finger. Double bird.

dialogues.speaker: SPEECH THERAPIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You didn’t lose your sense of humor. Maggie, Oliver and Daka walk in.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You have some company, Vin.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: I say hello only. The hospital is shit place. Oliver walks to Vin's bedside.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You look a lot better.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: (slurred, re: Therapist) Getttt this dippppshitt outta here. Oliver’s confused with Vin’s slurred speech.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Wha’dya say?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Getttt this...dipppppp... Vin gets frustrated, his mouth won’t work. He swipes hospital effects off the bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Getttttt outtta herrrrr. Maggie interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Okay, Oli. Let’s let Vin work with the therapist.

dialogues.speaker: SPEECH THERAPIST
dialogues.text: Thank you. We’1l be about an hour.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Fuccckkk you, annnnn hour.

dialogues.speaker: SPEECH THERAPIST
dialogues.text: Maybe less.  79. Maggie covers Oliver's ears.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Why mean, you are? You could stop breathing. Maggie pulls Daka and Oliver out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Let’s go get a snack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie, Oliver and Daka are sitting in the visitor’s lounge drinking coffee. Daka is eating a candy bar.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He may talk like that for a while. That's what happens sometimes when a person has a stroke.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: He sounds...

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Like the retard. Out of anyone else’s mouth that would be offensive.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, he’s a stupid man anyway. So retard is not far from. Daka finishes her candy bar.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you have a dollar? I’m starving. I eat nothing today. Maggie digs in her purse.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I do. She opens her wallet. Pulls out a dollar.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: I think dollar half is better. Maggie gives her two bucks.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Spasibo. She's off to the vending machines.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (re: her belly) Is that Vincent’s...?  80.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Baby?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yea.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I avoid the whole situation. It’s not polite to ask a woman if she’s pregnant. So.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Well. She’s obviously pregnant. So...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Vin's like 90 something. That would be inappropriate. Daka returns with two chocolate bars. She offers one to Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: If you hit this machine as first candy drops, you can get two to come down. Good? Oliver takes it. Unwraps. The three of them sit awkwardly comfortable together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time passes. Spring is in the air. -- A Homeless Guy, wearing shorts, soaks up the sun from a bus stop bench. -- The Buck. An ARTIST is painting the front window for St. Patty’s Day. -- Doctor's Office. Ozinski gets his nose bandage removed. His nose is completely crooked. -- Vin’s House. The lawn is out of control. A foot high. A MAILMAN bends down and puts mail in the toppled mailbox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daka is feeding Felix the Cat the usual: gourmet cat food.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Don't eat fast, shit. I don’t come for till tomorrow.  81. Daka looks at the stacks of dishes, mold, dirt, grime, shit everywhere. Fuck it. She rolls up her sleeves, turns the sink on. Starts to clean. INT. VIN’S HOSPITAL ROOM - ANOTHER DAY Vin’s perched in a recliner. Oliver is sitting on his bed shuffling a stack of flash cards.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Try this one. He holds up a card. It reads: “I want fresh crab.” Vin studies the card. Then:

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I waannnnnt fresssshh crap. Oliver looks at the card. Damn Vin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crespi’s class. Ozinski is presenting in front of the class. His voice is nasally, due to the “new” nose alignment.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: And for my real-life saint, I picked... He clicks the Smart Board. A picture of Oliver pops up. OZINSKI (CONT’D) Oliver Bronstein. He’s like one a them martyrs. Cause he was persecuted too, when he first got here. Mostly by me. And a few others, who I’m not gonna rat out. You know who you are. Ozinski stares directly at a few FELLAS in class. Brooklyn sinks in his chair. OZINSKI (CONT’D) Anyways. He’s my saint. Cause he forgave me for being such a dingleberry, when I was acting like an a-hole. The CLASS laughs. Oliver is all smiles. He’s a hundred feet tall.

dialogues.speaker: IMAGES OVER MUSIC
dialogues.text: -- Daka is vacuuming Vin’s living room. It sounds like she’s sucking up marbles. It’s so damn dirty.  82. -- Vin and Oliver are racing down a hallway in wheelchairs. It’s neck and neck. Vin'’s lit cigarette drops in his lap. Oliver wins. -- At a grocery store, Maggie and Oliver are buying cat food. Lots. -- Oliver wheels a piece of carryon luggage into Vin’s room. He lays the luggage carefully on the bed and unzips. Felix the Cat climbs out unaffected. -- Vin's sitting in a wheelchair outside the hospital (in street clothes.) A NURSE stands behind him. Daka pulls up in Vin’s car. Honks. Vin stands up, walks to the car using a cane. -- Driving. Daka can barely steer the car over her about- to-pop belly. Vin lights a cigarette. Daka snatches it out of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you? She tosses it out the window. INT. VIN’S HOUSE - LATER Living room. Daka leads Vin inside. The place is spotless.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Wherrre’s mmmmmy dirt?

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Vin’s sitting on his couch, looking around. The place is foreign to him. Daka waddles in with a plate of food. A turkey sandwich with a side of carrots. Healthy. Vin inspects.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Whhhhattt’re these?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Vegetables, what. You don’t see these?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Donnnnn’t eeeeat them.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: You do now, fuck. Vin picks up the sandwich. Takes a damn bite. What choice does he have?  83.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You pay me for the hours now, papa.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Whaaaattt for?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: What, for what? I take care of your ass. And we don’t bump the ugly parts no more. So don’t ask. I’m too fat for this and you’re too old. Vin thinks. Shakes his head in agreement. The sandwich is pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fifteen dollars for the hours. Plus the room and food. Daka walks out. Vin damn near chokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gray stone court house. A gray day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie, Oliver and their attorney, RICHARD WALTERS are on one side. On the other side: Oliver’s father, DAVID BRONSTEIN, tall, dark and disconnected, sits next to his attorney BARRY BRILLSTERN. JUDGE REYNOLDS presides, he’s examining a file full of photos.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: (directed to Richard) Who is Vincent Canatella? Richard is stumped. He turns to Maggie. RICHARD WALTERS, ESQ. You know him?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He’s our next door neighbor. He watches Oliver sometimes. RICHARD WALTERS, ESQ. Your honor, he’s my client’s neighbor. He occasionally watches Oliver. Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: He’s a baby sitter? Again, Richard turns to Maggie.  84.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes. Of sorts. I pay him. And Oliver goes there after school for a few hours while I’m at work. RICHARD WALTERS, ESQ. (to Judge) He’s a baby sitter, your honor. Of sorts. A paid position. May I ask why this is relevant? Judge Reynolds flips through more pictures.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: Is your client aware that Mr. Canatella takes her son to a race track and they gamble? He also takes him to a local bar, The Buck? And a strip club, The Pink Cadillac? Maggie is lost. She looks to Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: We went to see the horses a few times. Maggie could die. She turns back to Richard.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I...this...is news to me. RICHARD WALTERS, ESQ. My client is unaware of these events. As am I. Which is a big surprise, I must say, right now.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: I‘ll bet there are quite a few surprises in this folder then. Judge Reynolds holds up a pound of pictures. Maggie gasps.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, God.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: Daka Parimova? Are you aware of her occupation? Richard turns to Maggie. Maggie turns to Oliver. Oliver whispers in Maggie’s ear. She turns pale white. Maggie whispers in Richard’s ear. He goes blank. RICHARD WALTERS, ESQ. Your honor, I need a few minutes to confer with my client.  85. INT. MAGGIE’S COROLLA - LATER Driving. avoiding Maggie’s so mad, she’s past mad. Oliver's eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I guess gambling at the horse track is like a math lesson. Have to figure out how to bet and all that.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: The odds.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thank you. And the bar...well I imagine that could fall under current events.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: More like social studies.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Nice. It’s the strip club and the hooker that are the ones I can’t wrap my head around.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Commerce. And biology?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Don’t talk anymore. VIN'’S BACKYARD —- CONTINUOUS Vin’s wearing only underwear, watering the dirt pit he calls a lawn. It hasn’t seen water in a month. Maggie yells out from behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: vin! She yells louder. He turns.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: vin!

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Whyyy do you people think mmmmy people cannn’t hear?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What kind of man takes a child gambling, drinking, smoking?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Oh. Gooodie.  86.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hanging out with prostitutes.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What kind of mother leaves her son with a mannnnn like that? Ouch.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Vin.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Now we're talkinnnng.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Fifty-fifty custody with his asshole father now. I have you to thank for that.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You have yourrrrrrself to thank for that. He needs someone besides his deadbeat mother. That’s rough.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Good one. Maybe I deserve it. I left him with you. What the hell was I thinking?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Mmmmy sentiments exactly.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He can’t come over here anymore. That’s a given. I/’11 get that fence money to you real soon.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: They'll be sommmme interest. Maggie shakes her head, walks off. Vin squirts the hose, it hits Maggie's back.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorrrryy. I’m a littttle slower with the reaction time these days.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You were never fast. Just stupid. INT. VIN’S KITCHEN - NIGHT Vin sits at his counter. Looking at the biggest pile of bills and mail. He fishes through, tossing most aside. Eventually the answering machine comes into view. The red light is blinking.  87. Vin hits play.

dialogues.speaker: ANA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Vincent. This is Ana from Sunnyside. I have some news about your wife, Sandy, sir. INT. VIN’S CAR - THE NEXT DAY Daka is driving. Vin riding. The answering machine plays under.

dialogues.speaker: ANA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (another message) Mr. Vincent, this is Ana again at Sunnyside, sir. I’ve left you a few messages now. I hope that you are okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin’s walking down the hallway. The answering machine continues.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Canatella, this is Shirley Jorstin over here at Sunnyside. Sir, I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but your wife is dead. And she’s been dead for a few weeks now. And we haven’t heard from you. Which is concerning as well. SHIRLEY’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER Vin’s sitting at Shirley’s desk. Shirley enters with a box of personal items.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Oookay, Mr. Canatella. Here we go. Shirley sits. Puts the box on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All her personal items are in there, sir. Vin looks at the box.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Where is shhhee?

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: My wwwife.  88.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: She died, Mr. Canatella.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I know that. Where isss she?

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: (indicates the box) She’s in there, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: In the box. Her remains. Vin is speechless. For once.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She died a few weeks ago, Mr. Canatella. We tried to contact you several times. So there’s that. And when we didn’t hear back from you. Well. We just went ahead and followed your death directives, sir. She pushes a signed paper towards, Vin.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You did want her cremated. That’s what’s on the signed directives there. Vin looks at the paper, then back at the box.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: She’s in that bbbox?

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Her remains are, sir. Yes. Ina box inside that box. We can’t just keep a body lying around. I’m sure you understand. That would be inappropriate. And legally we just can’t do that, of course. You could imagine the litigation potential. Vin stands. Takes the box.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry for your loss, Mr. Canatella. Vin stares at here, then walks away.  89.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There is the other matter of your outstanding balance we should discuss. Vin keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: (over his back) I’11 maiilll it to you. He’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin’s sitting on the bench in front of the pond. Sandy’s spot. Daka sits next to him. The box in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: This place is peace.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: It wwwwas. He lights a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tellll mmme what’s in there, would ya. Daka opens the lid on the box.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: A photo picture of... Inspects it. Pulls it out. It’s Vin and Sandy’s wedding picture.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is this you? Vin nods.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is her? He nods again.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You go downhill.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You’1ll ggget there. She digs around in the box.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: There is another box. Like a suede or leather kind cover.  90.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Dddon’t touch that one. Fishes. Pulls out an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: This has “Vincent” on writing. Vin takes the envelope. Opens it. Official looking paperwork...and a key. Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver and Ozinski are sitting against a wall. A dodge ball game in progress in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: Being with your dad ain’t so bad. Least he’s around. And wants to see ya.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: My mom’s the one who hates it.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: That’s her problem. These woman gotta learn to let go. Oliver is impressed with the rare deep thought. OZINSKI (CONT’D) I’m seeing a shrink.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: That’s cool.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: My Ma’s makin’ me. Thinks me acting out all the time is due to the fact that my father left us and I got no positive male role model in my life. So I do bad shit to get attention.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What’s the shrink say?

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: He thinks my Ma is overbearing and controlling and actually I’m acting out to rebel against her.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: That makes more sense.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: That's what I’m fucking thinkin’.  gl.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You talk to her about it.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: No. She’d whop my ass. A whistle blows. The dodge ball game is over. Next up. OZINSKI (CONT’D) Let’s tag team these ass fags. You go high, I’1ll shoot for the nuts. Oliver and Ozinski run onto the court. EXT. ST. FRANCIS DE SALES —- SIDEWALKS After school. KIDS everywhere. Oliver’s walking out with Ozinski. A HORN honks. Maggie’s sitting in her car in parent pickup. INT. MAGGIE’S COROLLA - LATER Maggie’s driving. Oliver’s riding. And a strange Latin lady is sitting quietly in the backseat. This is AMELDA. Oliver’s new nanny. Short, stout, pointless.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s your father’s idea of safer child care.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Does she speak English?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to Amelda) Poquito?

dialogues.speaker: AMELDA
dialogues.text: Si.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Guess that’s good enough.

dialogues.speaker: AMELDA
dialogues.text: Si.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes. Si.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Everyday?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: And every other weekend when you go to your dad’s. Oliver’s not thrilled.  92.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s the deal now. You get shuffled back and forth between your father and I.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: He is my dad. Maggie takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know he cheated on you. A bunch of times. And that why we left.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You know that?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It’s a secret? You tell anybody who'll listen. Grandma, Aunt Judy, all the cousins. It’s also your Facebook status.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I been meaning to change that Maggie considers this.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll just say that I’m single. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - DAY Backyard. Vin’s sitting on a beach chair, staring at the box with Sandy in it, perched on the lawn table in front of him. Oliver walks around the side of the house. Amelda’s right behind him.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You cannnn’t be here.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Mom said I could say goodbye. Oliver just stands there. Not knowing what to say.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That mmmy replacement?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yea. I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: She 1llllegal? Amelda chimes in.  93.

dialogues.speaker: AMELDA
dialogues.text: Si.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Hate to havvvve to report your mother to the immagrrrration and naatturallll1111- (to fucking hard to say) (for Amelda) She comprendes. Amelda bulls up.

dialogues.speaker: AMELDA
dialogues.text: Mr. Oliver, vamanos. She makes her way back from where she came.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What’s in the box?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Mmmmmy wife.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: She...died?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: No. Sssshe shrunk herself and now she’s living in there rent free.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Oh. I’m really sorry, Vin.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Never understood wwwwhy people sssssay that.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: They don’t know what else to say.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Welllll, it’s a shit saying. How ‘bout, “What was she like?” “Do you miss her?” “What're ya gonna do now?” Oliver has no words.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listennnn. Do yourself a favor, kid, and get a life. Oookay. Stop living mine. It hasn’t been for shit.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: That’s not true. Vin lashes out.  94.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: The hhhell do you know about me? You act like I’m some kinda role model. Are you stupid? Oliver strikes back.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m stupid. Mostly for thinking you were more than just a drunk, mean, old man. Oliver starts to tear.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Don’t cry while your fighting.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Don’t teach me any more gems, Vin. Save ‘em for the nobody left in your life. Toe to toe. Vin backs down.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I guess that’s goodbye. Very touching.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Your sad. Oliver walks off. Vin stares at the box. VIN'S BEDROOM — CONTINUOUS Vin’s sitting on the bed. The box, next to him. He talks to it.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I loved you to the moon there, Sandy. Then...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So...what nnnnnow? Vin inspects the room: packed full of shit, memories, pictures. It hasn’t been touched since she left. Vin grabs a picture of himself and a FEW MARINES posing in Ho Chi Minh. He studies it. Then throws it in a bag. He grabs another picture. Then another. Throwing everything in site, all the memories, pictures, knickknacks into the bag. Purging.  95. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - NIGHT Vin drags two full trash bag loads of junk across the lawn. He dumps them into trash barrels. INT. OLIVER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Oliver watches Vin from his bedroom window. He shuts the blinds and sits on his bed. Thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Computer lab. Oliver, Ozinski and OTHER STUDENTS are working on computers, wearing headsets. Oliver digs in his backpack and pulls out Vin’s Vietnam picture. The one Vin tossed in the trash. He flips the picture over, reads the handwritten inscription: “la Drang, Vietnam, 1965. Sgt. Vincent Canatella.” Oliver pecks on his keyboard: Insert - Google search bar typing: “Sgt. Vincent Canatella.” The search reveals several pages with headings: “War Hero,” “Bronze Star,” “Sgt. Canatella Rescues Two Officers,” “The Battle of la Drang.” Etc. Oliver clicks on the first link and starts reading. A picture of a younger Vin pops up. He’s a proud looking soldier. Oliver hits Ozinski. He leans over and looks.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: (too loud) That’s the old fucker. Oliver nods. Everyone and their mother heard that. INT. CRESPI’S CLASS - LATER Crespi’s concluding class. As kids shuffle out.

dialogues.speaker: CRESPI
dialogues.text: Two weeks, children. The grand stage, as they say. Our “Saints” assembly. Don’t forget to invite your parents, significant others, etc., etc. Crespi stops Oliver and Ozinski.  96.

dialogues.speaker: CRESPI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No expletives in your presentation, Ozinski.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: My name’s Robert, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: He doesn’t like Ozinski, Brother Crespi. Never has. And with that the two boys walk off. INT. BANK — DAY Vin’s being escorted through the vault by his favorite banker, Terry. He’s looking through a file.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: She rented the box about eight years ago, Mr. Canatella. Prepaid to the end of this year actually. They stop in front of a row of safety deposit boxes.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to key in with you. Terry puts his key in the slot of a small box. Vin pulls his key out of his jacket. Keys in. It opens. Vin stares at Terry until...

dialogues.speaker: TERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll be outside, sir. Vin opens the door to the box. There’s only one thing inside of it: a trifold pamphlet. He pulls it out. Unfolds it. It’s a life insurance policy. Vin leans against the boxes. Shakes his head at the blessing.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER RESEARCHING, VIN MOVING ON
dialogues.text: EXT. OLIVER’S HOUSE - DAY Ozinski waits on his bike outside Oliver’s house. Oliver comes running out, jumps on the back of the bike. Amelda waddles out after him, holding a jacket. She puts the jacket on Oliver. And they take off.

dialogues.speaker: STREETS
dialogues.text: Oliver and Ozinski ride through traffic. Hauling ass.  97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ozinski’s bike is parked in front of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver and Ozinski are sitting at the bar drinking Shirley Temples. Oliver is interviewing Gus and Linda.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Oh heck, he won the Bronze Star in Vietnam. Pulled two officers out of an ambush in la Drang. Only a few got outta there.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: It’s famous. He never told ya about it?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: No, ma'am. Oliver takes notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vin’s car. Daka is driving. Vin directs.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Therrrre’s a spot. It's handicapped.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: We don’t park this spot. Vin pulls a handicapped parking placard from the glove box. Hangs it on the rear-view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Best thing that ever happened to me. Daka pulls in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zaucko's walking down a quiet breezeway, whistling. He turns a corner. CRACK! He’s hit in the face with a cane. Falls backwards, dazed, bleeding from the mouth. Teeth are gone. Vin hovers above him, waving his cane.  98.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That’ssss the for the elder abuse, asshole. Vin tosses an envelope on Zucko’s chest.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s my dues. Plus interest. Don’t come around no more. I’m done with the horses. Vin walks off, a spring in his step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chin-up bar. Oliver's pulling with all his might. A CROWD OF CLASSMATES, lead by Ozinski, scream him on from the ground.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: Oliver! Oliver! Oliver! Oliver! Coach Mitchell smiles, watching in anticipation. Oliver strains, pulls, twists. And finally, his chin goes over the bar. The kids erupt in cheers. Oliver drops like a sack of potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver is walking towards a new Jaguar parked in parent pickup. It’s his dad, David, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver and David are sitting in the window eating frozen yogurt. David's trying to connect.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So. How’s things?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Good. Can’t complain.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mom. Good?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Friends?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Dad. We don’t have to small talk. Whatever happened between you and mom, that’s your deal. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t want to be in the middle. We can just be us. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Got it. They eat in comfortable silence. Then...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How’s school? Oliver smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver is interviewing Nurse Ana. David's sitting on the lawn a few feet away, waiting. Oliver scribbles in his notebook, lots of notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David carries a sleeping Oliver into the house. Maggie holds the door open. INT. OLIVER’S ROOM - MOMENTS LATER David puts Oliver in bed. Maggie flips the light off. EXT. MAGGIE & OLIVER’S HOUSE - LATER Maggie and David stand by David's car. Awkwardness is all they know.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I can pick him up after school on Friday.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay, then.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yep. David gets into the car. Maggie knocks on the passenger window.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, this is okay. I’m okay with it. You’re his father. An asshole. But still his father. So. I’1l get over it. Just going to take some time.  100.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That’s all you’re going to say?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don’t disagree with anything you said. So.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Even the asshole part.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes. Even that. Maggie thinks.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Alright. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Good night. David drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver and Ozinski are loading a cart full of fence building materials. Pickets, posts, nails, etc.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK OUT COUNTER
dialogues.text: David pays for the supplies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David's SUV cruises down the road. Fencing supplies tied haphazardly to the roof. INT. VIN’S HOUSE - LATER Vin is peeking out the living room blinds. Watching Oliver, Ozinski and Amelda fixing his fence.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: (re: the fence) Ttthat’1l be straight. He shuts the blinds.  101. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Oliver, Ozinski and Amelda are working on the fence. Amelda’s the “foreman,” as she’s the only one who knows what she’s doing. Daka pulls up in Vin’s car. Lumbers down the driveway with a bag of groceries.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Does he know you fix this?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: He peeks through the blinds every few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: He don’t come looking?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: (disgusted) This one. Still play the stroke card. INT. NAT’S BROOKLYN DINER - ANOTHER DAY Oliver is interviewing Daka. Amelda is eating, along for the ride. Daka is holding a flier for Oliver's school assembly: “Saints Among Us.”

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Why you want him come see this? He’s big asshole.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I think he’s just misunderstood. By himself mostly.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Cause asshole, yes?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: That's a possibility. Jesus comes over, refills Daka’s coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: (to Jesus) Jesus. I look for job application. You have this?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Si.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: You bring for me?  102.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Si. Jesus is off. Oliver's impressed.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: They need someone speak English for here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. OLIVER’S HOUSE - THE NEXT MORNING Oliver’s room is full of Vin’s pictures. The memories rescued from the trash. Oliver’s getting ready for school. Standing in front of a mirror, tying a Windsor Knot on his tie. Maggie calls from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oliver. Breakfast is ready. Oliver furrows with confusion.

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Oliver walks in to find a full pancake breakfast. Bacon. Toast. The works. A big surprise in this household. Maggie’s pouring OJ.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Gotta have fuel for your big day. Oliver is touched.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I took the day off. He hugs his mom.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Thanks, mom.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You’re welcome, bub. Somehow Maggie’s become a mother.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Don’t get sentimental on me. She kisses his head.  103. INT. VIN’S LIVING ROOM —- CONTINUOUS Vin’s sitting is his Lazy Boy, zoned out on Abbott & Costello. Daka rushes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: I think my water is broken.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Calllll a plumber. She kicks his chair.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Get up. Fuck. Vin climbs out of his chair. Damn baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The auditorium is packed to the gills with STUDENTS, TEACHERS, PARENTS and GUESTS. The curtain opens and Brother Crespi’s entire class walks out and takes seats behind the on-stage podium. Oliver and Ozinski sit next to each other. Friends for life. A projection screen displays the banner, “Saints Among Us.” The CROWD applauds. INT. VIN’S CAR - MOMENTS LATER Daka is driving like a nut. Vin’s white knuckled. He tries to light a cigarette. Daka swipes it from his mouth, tosses it out the window.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: When you become like man? She shakes her head in disgust, then goes back to fake deep breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother Crespi steps up to the podium and announces the next speaker.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER CRESPI
dialogues.text: Our next speaker is Mr. Oliver Bronstein. The CROWD claps. Maggie hoots from her seat. She’s sitting next to ex-husband David. They may end up civil. Oliver walks up to the podium. Strong. Courageous. A different kid than the one who couldn’t utter a word in front of his class. He clears his throat.  104.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Saints are human beings we celebrate for their dedication and commitment to other human beings. Brother Cary Crespi, circa around January... Laughs. EXT. ST. FRANCIS DE SALES —- CONTINUOUS Daka whips the car into the school's lot. Pulls into a handicapped spot. Vin is suspect.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: This isn’t the hospital. Daka tosses the flier in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Get inside. Daka steps out of the car, moves on. Vin looks at the flier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver’s in mid-presentation. On the massive projection screen behind him, we see a portrait of St. William of Rochester. Click. The screen refreshes, and a picture of Vin pops up.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: For my modern day saint, I chose a man who shares many of the same qualities as St. William of Rochester: Mr. Vincent Canatella. He continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the auditorium. Vincent stands in front of a marquee board. It’s the “Saint Wall.” Under each student's name are two pictures: a real Saint next to a Modern Day Saint. Under Oliver Bornstein, we find: St. William of Rochester and...Vincent Canatella. And he’s one fucked-up looking “saint.” Eyes black, face distorted, assuredly on drugs, lying in his hospital bed. Vin stares at the picture of himself. He hears Oliver’s voice within. Walks to the auditorium doors.  105.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Canatella was born in Newark, NJ, in 1950, the son of first generation Italian immigrants. Vin cracks the door open. Just as he’s doing this a PRIEST comes up behind him and opens it the rest of the way.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: (whispers ) After you... Vin defaults. Walks in first. He stands at the back of the auditorium. Oliver continues:

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Growing up poor on the streets of New Jersey, Vincent learned all the things a kid shouldn’t need to know. Fighting, cursing and gambling. The slide show shuffles images of VINCENT AS A BABY. Then a YOUNG BOY. Poor. Tough. Street. Pictures of a hard life. All the memories Vin had tossed in the trash.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In 1965, as a member of United States Army’s 5th Regiment, Vincent was among the 450 soldiers dropped into the la Drang Valley, and immediately ambushed by 2000 enemy troops. A headshot of Vincent as a young Marine in Vietnam. Smoking a cigarette, proud, strong.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There he heroically saved the lives of two wounded officers pinned down by enemy fire and carried them to safety. Newspaper clippings of Vin’s heroics. A picture of Vin receiving the Bronze Star. In the back of the auditorium, Vin is frozen...seeing his life through the eyes of another.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I imagine the best way I can tell you who Vincent Canatella is...is to tell you what he’s done for me. For the first time, Oliver sees Vin standing in back.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When my mom and I first moved here, we knew no one. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And Mr. Canatella took me in. When he didn’t have to. And probably didn’t want to. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But he did it anyhow. That’s what saints do. A wedding picture of Vin and Sandy pops up on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We visited his wife of forty years, Sandy, who recently passed away. Vin's done her laundry every week for the past eight years, long after she no longer recognized him. Another picture of Vin and Sandy.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because saints never give up. A picture of VIN AS A FIGHTER, with boxing gloves on.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He taught me how to fight. How to stand my ground and be brave. How to speak up and be bold. Maggie is crying. David hands her a tissue.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because saints fight for themselves and others. So that they might be heard. Vin is glued, hearing what he means to another, is the warmth that melts an iceberg.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He taught me how to gamble. Horse racing, Keno, the over and under. Which is a big reason why I’m grounded till I’m eighteen. Laughs.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But in that I learned how to take risks and go for broke. Because in life the odds can be stacked against you. A picture of Vin’s cat, Felix.  107.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is Vin’s cat, Felix, who eats gourmet cat food. While Vin eats sardines. The CROWD loves it.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because saints make sacrifices. Maggie, David and Daka are mesmerized, proud, inspired.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Vincent Canatella is flawed. He’s rough, drinks too much, smokes and curses. He’s angry, mad at the world, and I’m sure full of regrets. Vin takes it in.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because after all, saints are human beings. Very human beings. The picture of St. William next to Vincent replays on the projection screen.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Courage, sacrifice, compassion and humanity. These are the markings of a saint. And what makes Mr. Vincent Canatella not so far removed from St. William of Rochester... Vin’s picture solos on the presentation.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And with that, I’d like to present my friend and baby sitter, Mr. Vincent Canatella for sainthood. And hereby proclaim him St. Vincent of Van Wyck street. The place is wild with applause. Vin doesn’t know what to do. People are looking around for him. Finally...he starts walking down the aisle. Brother Crespi helps Vin up the steps. And towards Oliver, who’s holding the “Saint Medal.” Vin steps in front of Oliver. He leans over as Oliver puts the medal around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.  108.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Thanks, kkkid. And...without warning...Vin gets a tear in his eye. Maybe for the first time in his life. PEOPLE rise in their seats to applaud him. Oliver hugs Vin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The break room. Oliver and Vin stand in front of a vending machine, considering their options. Vin’s wearing scrubs. His speech impediment is not so abstruse.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: They got the same selection from when I was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Surely not. They’d be really rotten by now.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Nah. They’re all jacked up on preservatives. Crap has the half life of plutonium. Oliver digs in his pocket for change.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got it. I owe you money anyhow. What’s it going to be?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: The hard pretzels.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Just what I was looking at. Vin puts coins in the slot.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hit the buttons would ya. If I do it, we’ll end up with Twinkies. Oliver keys in the selection.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: If you hit it just right...you can... Oliver hits the machine just as the bag of pretzels is about to drop.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: «+.get two for the price of one.  109. A second bag of pretzels drops down behind the first.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pretty cool. Oliver grabs both bags, hands one to Vin.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: And we call that stealing. Oliver thinks about it. A NURSE pops her head into the room.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Canatella, it’s about that time. Vin rushes off.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Hold your horses. Oliver stands there, eating his pretzels. He digs into his pockets, grabs some change and slips it in the coin slot. He walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daka is in the final stages of giving birth. She’s calm and focused. A DOCTOR between her legs calls out the final push. The BABY is crowning.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: One more time. Big breath. Big push.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: You say one more time every time you say.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: This time I mean it. You’re almost there. Daka pushes. And a BABY is born. The doctor does his thing, suctioning, inspecting.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Let me look. The doctor holds her up.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Here she is. The baby cries. A voice from the corner breaks the moment :  110.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What is it? Vin has one foot in the room, one out.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Black, white, ugly?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Get out now. Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with asking? A Nurse takes the baby.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (to Daka) You want him to cut the cord?

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: No. No touch the child.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I’m a little shaky. Let a professional handle that. The Nurse cuts the cord. Vin sneaks a closer look at the baby.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sure aren’t pretty when they pop out.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Get out of here. Vin walks off. Mumbles.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: When she’s doped up...no sense ‘a humor. The doctor rests the baby on Daka’s bosom.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: Come here. My little princessa. Let me hold you. INT. VIN’'S HOUSE - ANOTHER DAY A “family” dinner. Daka is serving a homemade meal of spaghetti and green beans. Fancy it’s not. Oliver and Ozinski sit on one side of the table. Maggie on the opposite side. The baby’s in a bassinet, set within a high chair. And Vin is in the captain’s seat.  111.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: (re: the food) It’s colorful. I’11 say that.

dialogues.speaker: DAKA
dialogues.text: How you try don’t say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I love green beans. Oliver jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Sure. Don’t get ‘em that often.

dialogues.speaker: OZINSKI
dialogues.text: My ma makes ‘em out of the can.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That's why your brain is stilted. Daka sits. Vin starts to dig in.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well. Beats hunger. By a hair. Everyone just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Don’t you want to say something?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: A blessing or something. Vin thinks. Lowers his head, closes his eyes. Thinks better.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I better not. Figures. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS The camera pulls back from the house, as the MAILMAN, on all fours on the front lawn, shoves mail in the felled box.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You waiting for a paper invitation? This crap ain’t good enough to eat cold.  112. We float past the “fixed” fence and up into the atmosphere above Brooklyn. FADE TO BLACK. The end.
